_comment: Created by EFisher on 24/01/2014 16:57:48 using v2.0
title: How have TIA investigation rates changed?
analysis_commentary: A transient ischemic attack (TIA) or 'mini stroke' is caused by a temporary disruption in the blood supply to part of the brain, which results in a lack of oxygen to the brain. This can cause symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as speech and visual disturbance and numbness or weakness in the arms and legs. However, a TIA does not last as long a stroke. The effects only last for a few minutes and are usually fully resolved within 24 hours. The risk of stroke within four weeks of a TIA can be as high as 20%. It is therefore vital that people with TIA are investigated quickly. The audit shows that the proportion of high-risk TIA inpatients and outpatients being investigated have both improved in 2012, with inpatients performing better overall. Low-risk outpatients performed highest out of all groups in both years. Low-risk inpatients is the only outcome to perform worse in 2012 going from 22% to 14% a decrease of eight percentage points in two years.
data_source: Royal College of Physicians, National Stroke Audit
